title: August 22
description:
Our annual trip to Berkeley Tuolumne Camp in Yosemite was cut short by a raging wildfire. The Rim Fire, as it is being called, caused camp to be evacuated on Tuesday, August 20.

As of today, Thursday, August 22, the Rim Fire covers 85 square miles and has almost reached Tuolumne Camp. We are safely back home and anxiously checking the news.

We hope our beloved camp survives this catastrophe.

Update Monday, Aug 26
Very sadly, the entire camp burned to the ground last evening, and the Rim Fire continues to grow. At more than 250 square miles, it's now the 14th largest fire in California history.

The pictures on the news show that the devastation is complete and total. We attended a ceremony in a Berkeley park today with hundreds of other campers to commemorate our beloved Berkeley Tuolumne Camp.

Update Oct 1
The Rim Fire turned out to be the third largest fire in California history, and the Sierra Nevada's most destructive fire in centuries. 400 square miles (257,314 acres) burned.

children.title: Cabin 2
children.description:
Sunday afternoon: during the last few miles on the road from Berkeley, the smell of forest fire was in the air but we didn't worry. We figured there was a small fire nearby but that it must be under control.

When we got to camp, we selected cabin #2.

children.title: Pathfinder
children.description:
As soon as we unpacked, Felix, Connor, Benjamin and Felix prepared for an epic game of Dungeons & Dragons.

Sadly, this game was never to take place.

children.title: Blue Jay
children.description:
Check out Milo's official Tuolumne 2013 shirt. Lucie designed it!

She won the 2013 T-shirt design contest but nobody had bothered to notify her. What a pleasant surprise!

Her reward: one free T-shirt for each kid.

children.title: Heather
children.description:
Heather and her kids joined us at camp this year.

Heather spent a lot of time chillaxin' in the adirondack chairs with a big stack of reading material.

children.title: Patrick
children.description: Patrick's favorite Tuolumne activity: strumming his guitar.

children.title: Nico
children.description: Heather's son Nico is a fishing fanatic. He spent his trip with a fishing rod in his hands and his feet in the river.

children.title: Beaver Rock
children.description:
That's Milo on the top of Beaver Rock.

It's a tough climb. Lucie has scrapes on her knees to prove it. Milo's much better at it than she is.

children.title: Jump!
children.description: Milo, jumping off Beaver Rock.

children.title: David
children.description: David and his son Gabriel were at camp too.

children.title: Swimming Hole
children.description:
That mountain water is cold!

Milo warms up on the hot rocks like a lizard.

children.title: Climbing
children.description: Watching people attempt to climb Beaver Rock is a good spectator sport.

children.title: Bullseyes
children.description:
Felix and Connor got official Bullseye Awards for their performance at archery.

Good job, guys!

children.title: Award
children.description: When you shoot bullseyes not only do you get a certificate, you also get mentioned during post-meal announcements.  You get a round of applause from everyone in the dining hall.

children.title: Ashes
children.description: All Monday morning the air was smokey. Around lunchtime, ash started to rain down on camp.

children.title: D&D
children.description:
Monday after lunch, a group of us hiked to Small Falls.

The boys declined the offer. Who wants to go enjoy Mother Nature when one could stay in one's cabin working on role-playing character sheets?

Patrick and Connor decided to drive to Groveland, the nearest town, to take some pictures of the fire. The road to Groveland has a sweeping view of the valley.

This turned out to be a fateful decision for Patrick and Connor.

children.title: Flakes
children.description:
Returning from our hike, camp was covered with a layer of grey flakes.

3:00 pm: the electricity went out.

3:30 pm: we learned the fire had crossed Highway 120 between us and Groveland. Patrick and Connor were trapped on the other side of the flames!

4:00 pm: we tried to use the camp's land line to call Patrick (there is no cellphone reception at camp) but the phone lines had just gone down.

children.title: Red Sun
children.description:
4:30 pm: a bunch of people from San Jose Family Camp showed up. Their camp, a few miles closer to the fire, had just been evacuated. They stayed a few hours then moved on.

Meanwhile the sun had turned an apocalyptic red. The air was smokey and breathing was a little difficult. It felt oppressive and doom-ful.

We decided to pack our car just in case we had to leave in a hurry. We left out only our sleeping gear and a few essentials (chocolate, swim suits, Magic the Gathering cards...).

children.title: Red Skin
children.description:
The entire sky had a surreal glow, giving everyone and everything a reddish tone.

Still, the show must go on. Camp activities continued as normally as possible.

Heather reads a book to her son Benjamin, who turned 10 that very day.

Happy Birthday, Benjamin!

children.title: Dinner
children.description:
No electricity meant dinner by lantern light.

Kudos to the staff for managing to cook and serve dinner at all! Thankfully, the kitchen has gas stoves.

children.title: Announcements
children.description:
After dinner, Craig the camp manager gave us an update. The fire had grown from 800 to 4,000 acres just that day, with zero percent containment. Electricity and phones wouldn't come back anytime soon. However, the sheriff department assured him we were in no immediate danger so camp was still in session.

Craig had managed to secure some extra fuel for our emergency generators (to operate the sewage pumps) so he was optimistic we could keep enjoying camp the rest of the week.

children.title: Worried
children.description:
Despite Craig's upbeat attitude, the vibe in the dining hall was spooky.

Many families decided to leave that evening. Among them were Heather and her posse of young boys (her sons, their friend + an exchange student from France).

children.title: Panic
children.description:
We were given instructions on what to expect in case of an emergency evacuation.

Now might be a good time to panic!

Still, to Lucie, the prospect of driving on mountain roads at night was scarier than the possibility of an emergency evacuation in the middle of the night. She decided to stay.

children.title: Last Stand
children.description:
Benjamin, Heather and French exchange student Max puts on a brave face before heading off on the long road home.

Because Highway 120 was shut down by the Rim Fire, the only way out was the much longer route through Yosemite National Park -- a detour of several hours.

children.title: Farewell
children.description:
Last group photo before we part.

Is it just me or are Benjamin and Max's smiles a little tense?

children.title: Smokey
children.description:
Monday night: all the remaining campers enjoyed a nice campfire complete with songs, a strumming guitar and s'mores for the kids. The sky was a weird shade of yellow and very smokey.

Milo slept like a rock but Felix and Lucie didn't get much shut-eye due to the noise of the emergency generator, the smell of smoke, the occasional fire-fighting planes overhead, a few rolls of thunders and of course the stress that the evacuation alarm might come any second.

children.title: Tent Chart
children.description:
Tuesday morning: we woke up to clear blue skies. The smell of smoke was gone. We didn't feel in danger anymore.

Lunchtime: the sheriff dropped by and explained we were in no immediate danger and that we should enjoy ourselves. The Rim Fire was still raging but the wind had turned away from us.

Still, the mood was a bit spooky. More and more families filtered out throughout the day. Only a third of the cabins were now occupied, as you can tell from the tent chart. Camp was starting to feel deserted.

children.title: Tie Die
children.description:
Every Tuesday is Tie-Die Day at Camp Tuolumne. For the first time in our six years of camp we remembered to bring white shirts to participate!

Lucie was thrilled the activity wasn't canceled despite the less-than-optimal conditions.

children.title: Rubber Bands
children.description: First, you tie rubber bands either randomly or in strategic patterns.

children.title: Soak
children.description: Second,  you soak your shirt in soda ash water. The soda ash helps fix the dye.

children.title: Squirt
children.description: Third,  you squirt dyes of various colors.

children.title: Last Step
children.description:
Camp counselors usually take care of the last steps: letting the tied fabric rest in a plastic bag for 24 hours, rinsing it thoroughly in cold water and washing it with Synthrapol.

But without electricity, the camp's washing machines were out of commission. We took our soaking creations home with us with a little container of Synthrapol for the last step.

children.title: Sawmill Road
children.description:
Also Tuesday morning: we heard we might be able to get cell phone reception by driving up Sawmill Road.

From the top of Sawmill Road we got a sweeping view of the fire (well, okay, mostly massive plumes of smoke with a reddish glow at the base).

Cell reception was very poor. No voice. We managed to send Dean a couple of texts after many tries.

children.title: Gabriel
children.description:
We spent Tuesday afternoon frolicking in the swimming hole.

Hi, Gabriel!

children.title: Raft
children.description:
Isaiah and Milo are ready to attack!

4:00 pm: swim time was cut short because the staff was called for an emergency meeting.

Soon after, a bus from the City of Berkeley came to pick up all the CIT (Counsellors In Training) and other staff under 18. Their parents back in Berkeley were worried and wanted them home.

children.title: Ready
children.description:
Felix had a good afternoon. He creamed his little brother in a water fight (see his water gun) and he shot gobs of bulleyes at archery (see his bow and duct tape quiver).

5:30 pm: we were told supper would be served early, as in RIGHT NOW. Something was off. For dessert, they gave us all the ice cream from the sweet shop. Previously they had refused to open the freezers since electricity was out, but now they were giving it all away for free.

Then came the evening announcements. Felix got the next to last one: he shot 12 bullseyes at archery! Round of applause. Last announcement: we have 24 hours to evacuate.

Craig the camp manager stressed he would prefer everyone leave that night so the staff could focus on closing down camp the next day. Still, we were welcome to stay the night if we wanted.

children.title: Evacuation
children.description:
We were already pretty much fully packed, including all the gears left behind by Patrick and Connor.

As we added the last few items to our cars, the sheriff showed up again. New directive: we didn't have 24 hours after all. Everyone needed to evacuate ASAP.

Lucie and the kids were on the road 5 minutes later.

children.title: Vista Point
children.description: The view was jaw-dropping from the first vista point of our evacuation. Flaming red sky. Billowing smoke. Hint of orange flames through the grey ashes. Raging. Immense. Wow.

children.title: Perimeter
children.description:
We arrived back in Berkeley at midnight. Since then we've been anxiously following the news.

As of Wednesday morning: the fire had spread to more than 16,000 acres (25 square miles). Nearly 900 personnel were battling the blaze.

As of Thursday morning: the fire had jumped to nearly 54,000 acres (84 square miles). There's now a DC 10 airplane on the scene (one of only two firefighting DC 10s in the nation). That's a plane the size of a passenger jet, spraying retardant.

Sawmill Mountain Road, where we tried to make phone calls on Tuesday, is now engulfed in flames.

Berkeley Tuolumne Camp is apparently still unharmed, but the fire is coming dangerously close.

San Jose Family Camp, whose evacuees stopped briefly at Tuolumne Camp, is surrounded by the blaze but hasn't burned down because of heroic "structure defense" efforts by some of the 1,300 firefighters now on the scene.

The governor of California has declared a state of emergency for Tuolumne County.

Source: U.S. Forest Service

children.title: Smoke
children.description:
Here are a few photos from the news. The flames are over 100 feet high.

We were surprised when the plume of smoke could be seen all the way from Lake Tahoe. However, now the smoke has even reached Nevada and is nearly to the borders of Oregon and Idaho. It's creating its own weather patterns.

Photo from California Fire News

children.title: Raging
children.description:
The weather forecast couldn't be worse: very hot and high winds. The Rim Fire is progressing very fast, even at night.

The mountain gullies and rough terrain make it nearly impossible for firefighters to find out where it's burning, or create fire breaks to stop it.

This has been the driest year in California since records began more than 100 years ago.

Photo from Getty Images

children.title: Devastation
children.description:
Even if the structures of our beloved camp are saved by the firefighters, we fear the area around camp won't be the same for many years to come.

The wildfire is leaving behind post-apocalyptic landscapes of desolation.

Photo by Vivian Ho

children.title: ABC News
children.description:
Sunday evening, Aug 25: After days of us anxiously watching the news and hoping the fire wouldn't come any closer, it did. Camp Tuolumne burned to the ground.

The destruction seems complete. All the buildings for sure, but you can rebuild those. The trees will take many, many years to come back.

It happened the day our family was supposed to have left. And what should have been the last day of camp for the year.

children.title: D-Hall
children.description: View of Beaver Rock and D-Hall from the swimming hole.

children.title: Memorial
children.description:
Monday, Aug 26: Friends of Tuolumne Camp congregated in Civic Center Park in Berkeley to commemorate our beloved institution.

There were camp counselors, old friends, and lots and lots of Camp Tuolumne tee shirts. We swapped stories of camp and lit candles.

children.title: KTVU
children.description: We had our 8 seconds of fame as evacuees of the Rim Fire on KTVU, Oakland's TV News station.

children.title: Song Circle
children.description:
We sang all the old songs, even the silly ones. Especially the silly ones.

Goodbye for many years, Camp Tuolumne. We miss you already.
